revision.comment: Never once heard of it as "inter rules"
revision.text:
{{for|the senior men's competition between the AFL and GAA|International Rules Series}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2013}} {{infobox sport | name = International rules football | image = International rules.jpg | imagesize = 205px | caption = An international rules football match at the [[Etihad Stadium (Melbourne)|Etihad Stadium]] in [[Melbourne]], [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]], Australia, between [[Australia international rules football team|Australia]] and [[Ireland international rules football team|Ireland]] | union = {{plainlist| *[[Australian Football League]] *[[Gaelic Athletic Association]]}} | nickname = IR, International rules, Compromise rules | first = 1967 ([[Australian Football World Tour]]) | registered = | clubs = | contact = Yes | team = 15 | mgender = Single (male only at elite level) | category = Outdoor | ball = [[Ball (Gaelic football)|Gaelic football]] | olympic = No |paralympic=No }} '''International rules football''' ({{lang-ga|Peil na rialacha idirnáisiunta}}; also known as '''international rules''' in [[Australia]] and '''compromise rules''' in [[Ireland]]) is a [[team sport]] consisting of a [[Hybrid sports|hybrid]] of [[football]] codes, which was developed to facilitate international representative matches between [[Australian rules football]] players and [[Gaelic football]] players. The first tour, known as [[the Australian Football World Tour]], took place in 1967, with matches played in [[Ireland]], the [[United Kingdom]], and the [[United States]]. The following year, games were played between [[Australia]] and a touring [[Meath GAA|County Meath]] Gaelic football team, Meath being the reigning [[1967 All-Ireland Senior Football Championship Final|All-Ireland senior football champions]].{{cite web|url=http://www.footystamps.com/ot_int_rules.htm|title=History of International Rules Football|accessdate=18 April 2008}} Following intermittent international tests between Australia and Ireland, the [[International Rules Series]] between the senior [[Australian international rules football team]] and [[Ireland international rules football team]] has been played intermittently since 1984, and has generally been a closely matched contest. The sport has raised interest and exposure in developing markets for Gaelic and Australian football and has been considered a development tool by governing bodies of both codes, particularly by the [[AFL Commission]]. International rules football does not have any dedicated clubs or leagues. It is currently played by men's, women's, and junior teams only in [[tournament]]s or Test matches. ==Rules== The rules are designed to provide a compromise or combine between those of the two codes, with Gaelic football players being advantaged by the use of a round ball and a rectangular field measured about 160 yards long by 98 yards wide (Australian rules uses an oval ball and field), while the Australian rules football players benefit from the opportunity to [[tackle (football move)|tackle]] by grabbing between the shoulders and thighs and pulling to the ground, something banned in Gaelic football. The game also introduces the concept of the [[mark (Australian football)|mark]], from Australian rules football, with a free kick awarded for a ball caught from a kick of over 15 metres, where the kick must be in the forward direction if originating from a teammate. A player must bounce, solo (kick into one's own hands) or touch the ball on the ground once every 10 metres or six steps. A maximum of two bounces per possession are allowed, while players can solo the ball as often as they wish on a possession. Unlike in Gaelic football, the ball may be lifted directly off the ground, without putting a foot underneath it first. Players however cannot scoop the ball off the ground to a team-mate, nor pick up the ball if they are on their knees or on the ground. If a foul is committed, a free kick will be awarded, though referees (called umpires in Australian Rules) can give the fouled player advantage to play on at their discretion. [[File:International Rules Football scores.png|thumb|500px|Scoring in International rules football]] The game uses two large posts usually sets 6.5 metres apart, and connected 2.5 metres above the ground by a [[Goal (sport)|crossbar]] with a goal net that could extend behind the goalposts and attached to the crossbar and lower goalposts, as in Gaelic football. A further 6.5 metres apart on either side of those and not connected by a crossbar are 2 small posts, known as behind posts, as in Australian rules football. Points are scored as follows *Under the crossbar and into the goal net (a goal): 6 points, umpire waves a green flag and raises both index fingers.{{cite news |first=Paddy |last=Heaney |title=The rules of engagement: A brief guide |work=[[The Irish News]] |page=58 |date=23 October 2008 |accessdate= |quote= |url= }} * Over the crossbar and between the two large posts (an over): 3 points, umpire waves red flag and raises one arm above his head. * Between either of the large posts and small posts (a behind): 1 point, umpire waves white flag and raises one index finger. Scores are written so as to clarify how many of each type of score were made as well as, like Australian football, giving the total points score for each team; for example, if a team scores one goal, four overs and 10 behinds, the score is written as 1-4-10 (28), meaning one goal (six points) plus 4 overs (4 × 3 = 12 points) plus 10 behinds (10 × 1 = 10 points), for a total score of 28 points. An international rules match lasts for 72 minutes (divided into four quarters of 18 minutes each). Inter-county Gaelic football matches go on for 70 minutes, divided into two halves, and Australian rules matches consist of four 20 minute quarters of game time, although with the addition of [[Time on (Australian rules football)|stoppage time]], most quarters actually last between 25 and 30 minutes. As in Gaelic football, teams consist of fifteen players, including a [[goalkeeper]], whereas eighteen are used in Australian rules (with no keeper). ===2006 rule changes=== A number of rule changes were introduced before the 2006 International Rules Series: * Time per quarter was reduced from 20 minutes to 18 minutes. * A player who received a red card is to be sent off and no replacement is allowed; in addition to this a penalty is awarded regardless of where the incident takes place. (Previously a replacement ''was'' allowed and a penalty was only awarded if the incident happened in the penalty area.){{cite web|url=https://www.rte.ie/sport/gaa/2006/0125/200635-international/|title=Rule changes for International series agreed |website=Rte.ie |date=2007-06-14 |accessdate=2017-03-15}} * A yellow card now means a 15-minute [[penalty box|sin bin]] for the offending player, who will be sent off if he receives a second card.[https://www.rte.ie/sport/gaa/2006/0125/200635-international/] ===2008 rule changes=== * Maximum of 10{{cite news |first=Paddy |last=Heaney |title=Time for talk is over |work=[[The Irish News]] |page=58 |date=23 October 2008 |accessdate= |quote= |url= }} interchanges per quarter. * Teams are allowed only four consecutive hand passes (ball must then be kicked). * Match time reduced from 80 minutes to 72 minutes (18 minutes per quarter). * The goalkeeper can no longer kick the ball to himself from the kick-out. * Suspensions may carry over to GAA and AFL matches if the Match Review Panel sees fit. * A dangerous "slinging" tackle will be an automatic red card. * A [[Shepherding (Australian rules football)#Bumping|front-on bump]] (known as a shirtfront in Australian football) endangering the head will result in a red card. * Physical intimidation can result in a yellow card. * The keeper cannot be tackled or touched when the keeper is charging. * An independent referee can cite players for reportable offences from the stands. * Yellow card sin bin reduced to 10 minutes. ===2014 rule changes=== * Maximum number of interchanges per quarter increased from 10 to 16. * Unlimited number of interchanges allowed at quarter and half time breaks. * Number of consecutive hand-passes teams are allowed increased from 4 to 6. * Marks will not be paid for backwards kicks caught by a teammate. * Goalkeepers required to kick the ball out beyond the 45 m line after all wides, behinds and overs. * Failure of a goalkeeper to kick over the 45 m line will result in a free kick to the opposition (from the 45 m line).{{cite web|url=http://www.rte.ie/sport/gaa/international-rules/2014/0722/632344-no-more-short-kick-outs-for-international-rules/ |title=No more short kick-outs for International Rules |website=Rte.ie |date=2014-07-22 |accessdate=2017-03-05}} ===Women's international rules football=== {{see also|Australia women's international rules football team}} While [[ladies' Gaelic football]] has been growing almost exponentially since the 1970s, [[Women's Australian rules football]] has far fewer players, though numbers have grown strongly since the 1990s. In early 2006, representatives of the [[Ladies' Gaelic Football Association]] and Women's Australian Football Leagues met at a Ladies' Gaelic football festival in [[Singapore]], and agreed to compete in the hybrid version of the two football codes to coincide with the senior men's series. The 2006 Women's Series has been the only series to take place. {| class="wikitable" |+2006 Women's Series !| Date || Teams || Stadium || Location || Attendance || |- | 31 October 2006 || Ireland 6.26.16 (134) def.
Australia 1.2.3 (15) || [[Breffni Park]] || [[Cavan]] || || {{cite web|url=http://www.irishexaminer.com/breakingnews/ireland/cwidmhcwcwkf/|title=Breffni Park hosts first-ever women's International Rules tie|date=2006-10-31|accessdate=2009-10-26|work=[[Irish Examiner]]}}{{cite web|url=http://www.worldfootynews.com/article.php/20061109110343227|title=Brave Aussie ladies like ewes to the slaughter in Ireland|date=2006-11-14|accessdate=2013-05-22|publisher=''World Footy News''}} |- | 4 November 2006 || Ireland 3.5.6 (39) def.
Australia 0.4.6 (18) || [[Parnell Park]] || [[Dublin]] || || |} ===Juniors=== Among the first schoolboys' international tests was that played in Melbourne in 1983, when a Victorian under-17 team played Ireland. An interesting twist in these compromise matches is that the ball used was the oval shaped Australian football rather than the round ball.{{cite web| url=http://naa12.naa.gov.au/scripts/PhotoSearchItemDetail.asp?M=0&B=11571901&SE=1| title=Image A6180, 29/7/83/11| publisher=National Archives of Australia| accessdate=6 January 2008}} An official junior series at Under-17 level has been played in alternate nations since the early 2000s. Ireland completed a hat-trick of series wins from 2003–2005 before Australia won the junior series for 2006. The junior series was largely instituted by both leagues as a means to identify emerging talent. It has since been abandoned. {| class="wikitable" |+2005 Junior Series !| Date || Result || Venue Location || Age || Notes |- | 2005 Game 1 || Ireland 73 def.
Australia 32 || [[Crossmaglen]], [[County Armagh]] || U/17 || {{cite web|author=Peter Parry |url=http://www.worldfootynews.com/article.php/20050405042348267 |title=Ireland take U-17 IR series 2-1 |publisher=World Footy News |date= |accessdate=2017-03-05}} |- | 2005 Game 2 || Ireland 44 def. by
Australia 56 || [[Dublin]], [[County Dublin]] || U/17 || |- | 2005 Game 3 || Ireland 39 def.
Australia 31 || [[Killarney]], [[County Kerry]] || U/17 || |} *'''Australian player of the series:''' [[Joel Selwood]] *'''Irish player of the series:''' Ray Cullivan {| class="wikitable" |+2006 Junior Series !| Date || Result || Venue Location || Age || Notes |- | 2006 Game 1 || Australia 0.11.6 (39) drew
Ireland 2.7.6 (39) || [[Docklands Stadium]], [[Melbourne]] || U/17 || {{cite web|author=Peter Parry |url=http://www.worldfootynews.com/article.php/20060418060253369 |title=Two drawn Tests and Under 17's series rests on Fremantle Test |publisher=World Footy News |date= |accessdate=2017-03-05}} |- | 2006 Game 2 || Australia 1.6.11 (35) drew
Ireland 3.4.5 (35) || [[Football Park]], [[Adelaide]] || | U/17 || |- | 2006 Game 3 || Australia 2.6.15 (45) def.
Ireland 1.6.6 (30) || [[Fremantle Oval]], [[Perth]] || U/17 || {{cite web|author=Peter Parry |url=http://www.worldfootynews.com/article.php/20060420060624315 |title=Australia win decider in youth IR series |publisher=World Footy News |date= |accessdate=2017-03-05}} |} *'''Irish player of the series:''' Kevin Nolan *'''Australian player of the series:''' [[Bryce Gibbs (Australian rules footballer)|Bryce Gibbs]] ===Amateurs=== The [[Australian Amateur Football Council]] has sent an amateur Under-23 All-Australian team to Ireland in both 2005 and 2008. The Australian amateur team wore a different jersey to the AFL representative side, dark green and gold, with a kangaroo emblem. Recently, the [[Victorian Amateur Football Association]] (VAFA) has sent a squad of players sourced from the top six divisions of its competition to tour Ireland and play various clubs and representative teams.{{cite web|url=http://www.vafa.com.au/index.php?id=13&tx_ttnews%5Btt_news%5D=667&cHash=c81f94e093|title=Big V in Ireland|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131006165653/http://www.vafa.com.au/index.php?id=13&tx_ttnews%5Btt_news%5D=667&cHash=c81f94e093|archivedate=6 October 2013}} {| class="wikitable" |+Amateur matches !| Date || Teams || Stadium || Location || Attendance || Notes |- | 2005 || [[Australian Amateur Football Council|AAFC]] (U-23) 17 def. by

[[Na Piarsaigh GAA|Na Piarsaigh]] 16 || Páirc Uí Chonaire || [[Cork City]], [[County Cork]] || || {{cite web|url=http://www.vafa.com.au/index.php?id=219&tx_ttnews%5Byear%5D=2013&tx_ttnews%5Bmonth%5D=10&tx_ttnews%5Btt_news%5D=1269&cHash=caba0dafdd87aef2f3ee898f70830a7d |title=Big V Smashes Cork|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140306155405/http://www.vafa.com.au/index.php?id=219&tx_ttnews%5Byear%5D=2013&tx_ttnews%5Bmonth%5D=10&tx_ttnews%5Btt_news%5D=1269&cHash=caba0dafdd87aef2f3ee898f70830a7d|archivedate=6 March 2014}} |- | 2013 || [[VAFA]] 0.10.9 (39) def. by
Combined Dublin Universities 4.10.3 (57) || St Vincent's GAA Club || [[Marino, Dublin]], County Dublin || || {{cite web|url=http://www.vafa.com.au/index.php?id=219&tx_ttnews%5Byear%5D=2013&tx_ttnews%5Bmonth%5D=10&tx_ttnews%5Btt_news%5D=1273&cHash=46c216db92ae0e539cfd8a1b9a5dce84|title=VAFA Fall to Combined Dublin Universities|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140306155346/http://www.vafa.com.au/index.php?id=219&tx_ttnews%5Byear%5D=2013&tx_ttnews%5Bmonth%5D=10&tx_ttnews%5Btt_news%5D=1273&cHash=46c216db92ae0e539cfd8a1b9a5dce84|archivedate=6 March 2014}} |} ===Masters=== International rules also has a [[masters (sport)|masters]] category with several competitions. There is also a Masters International Rules Series which follows the format of the senior men's series and involves many retired Australian Rules and Gaelic Football players. ==International rules football around the world== [[File:Intrules.jpg|thumb|The June 2014 International Rules match at the University of Birmingham]] International rules is played in various locations throughout North America and the Caribbean, Europe, Asia, and Australia and New Zealand between fledgling Australian rules football and Gaelic football clubs. In 2006, an exhibition match between South African youth teams and an [[Indigenous Australian]] touring side composed of players from the [[Clontarf Foundation]], led by [[Sydney Swans|Sydney]]'s [[Adam Goodes]], was held at [[Potchefstroom, North West|Potchefstroom]]. The [[University of Birmingham]], UK, holds an annual International Rules match between its Australian Rules football team and its Gaelic Football team, with the 2013 edition won by the Australian Rules team 56–55, before a crowd of over 400 students.{{cite news|first=|last=|title=Aussie Rules claim victory against Gaelic Football|work=[[University of Birmingham]]|page=|date=6 June 2013|accessdate=14 June 2013|quote=|url=http://www.sport.bham.ac.uk/news.aspx?itemid=3781&itemTitle=Aussie+Rules+claim+victory+against+Gaelic+Football&sitesectionid=32&sitesectiontitle=Latest+News|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131004215226/http://www.sport.bham.ac.uk/news.aspx?itemid=3781&itemTitle=Aussie+Rules+claim+victory+against+Gaelic+Football&sitesectionid=32&sitesectiontitle=Latest+News|archivedate=4 October 2013|df=dmy-all}} In the [[International Rules Series]], the most well-known International Rules event, Australia and Ireland are at an impasse, with 10 series wins apiece. Most recently in 2017, Australia defeated Ireland with two Test wins and an aggregate score of 116-103. ==See also== * [[Australian rules football]] * [[Gaelic football]] * [[Relationship between Gaelic football and Australian rules football]] * [[International Rules Series]] ** [[Australia international rules football team]] ** [[Ireland international rules football team]] * [[Composite rules shinty-hurling]] * [[Hybrid sports]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20101211084716/http://gaa.ie/about-the-gaa/international-rules/Background/ International rules pages at the Gaelic Athletic Association website] * [http://www.afl.com.au/internationalrules/history International rules pages at the Australian Football League website] * [http://www.worldfootynews.com/index.php?topic=internationalrules WFN international rules] A catalogue of some of the scores of games in the code around the world. * [http://www.gaa.ie/mm//Document/MyGAA/Gettinginvolved/12/21/83/LawsofInternationalFootball2014_English.pdf Laws of the game (Updated in 2014)] * [http://www.afleurope.org/ AFL Europe Page] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20081101154659/http://www.tariksport.com/intrules.shtml Tarik's International Rules football results and rankings] {{Navboxes | list1 = {{International Rules Series}} {{Hybrid sport}} {{Team sports}} {{Gaelic football}} {{Australian rules football}} }} [[Category:International rules football| ]] [[Category:Football codes]] [[Category:Sports originating in Ireland]] [[Category:Sports originating in Australia]] [[Category:Variations of Australian rules football]] [[Category:Hybrid sports]] [[Category:Games and sports introduced in 1967]]

{{Use Australian English|date=December 2011}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2011}} {{Infobox person | name = Joffa Corfe | image = Joffa Corfe - Nth Melbourne, May 2011.jpg | caption = Joffa Corfe, May 2011 | birth_date = 7 July 1964 | birth_place = [[Preston, Victoria]] |occupation = Welfare worker |residence = Footscray |website = }}
'''Jeff "Joffa" Corfe''' (born 7 July 1964) is an [[Australian rules football]] supporter best known for being the leader of the [[Collingwood Football Club]] cheer squad since 2001.
==Gold jacket== Corfe rose to prominence in 2002 by donning a gold jacket and holding up a "Game Over" banner during games when he felt Collingwood had secured victory, usually in the fourth quarter.<ref name="heraldsun1">{{cite news|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/victoria/joffa-gets-the-flick-by-the-pies/story-e6frf7kx-1111118107096|title=Collingwood Football Club gives Joffa the flick |last=Brown|first=Terry|date=22 November 2008|publisher=''Herald Sun''|accessdate=20 January 2010}}</ref> The jacket came from the [[Nine Network|Channel Nine]] wardrobe and had been previously worn by [[Bernard King (television)|Bernard King]] and [[Tommy Hanlon, Jr.|Tommy Hanlon Jr]]. When Corfe saw [[Eddie McGuire]] wear it on ''[[The AFL Footy Show|The Footy Show]]'', he emailed McGuire to ask if he could use it to celebrate Collingwood victories. McGuire had the jacket drycleaned and handed it over at a [[Victoria Park, Melbourne|Victoria Park]] training session.<ref name="joffa1">{{cite web|url=http://joffasfrontpage.com/2.html|title=The Gold Jacket|last=Corfe|first=Jeff|publisher=joffasfrontpage.com|accessdate=20 January 2010}}</ref><ref name="age3">{{cite web|url=http://www.theage.com.au/articles/2003/07/23/1058853139580.html|title=Gold old Collingwood|last=McClure|first=Geoff|date=24 July 2003|publisher=''Herald Sun''|accessdate=20 January 2010}}</ref>
Before the [[2003 AFL Grand Final]], Corfe announced that he was going to discontinue use of the jacket, however after Collingwood's loss, he suggested that the jacket would make a comeback the next season.<ref name="age1">{{cite news|url=http://www.theage.com.au/articles/2003/09/24/1064083057940.html?from=storyrhs|title=Joffa jacket's final cheer|last=McClure|first=Geoff|date=25 September 2003|publisher=''The Age''|accessdate=20 January 2010}}</ref><ref name="age2">{{cite news|url=http://www.theage.com.au/articles/2003/11/10/1068329486509.html|title=Pies' grim days ahead|last=McClure|first=Geoff|date=11 November 2003|publisher=''The Age''|accessdate=20 January 2010}}</ref><ref name="age4">{{cite news|url=http://www.theage.com.au/articles/2003/09/28/1064687668699.html?from=storyrhs|title=Jacket not over yet|last=McClure|first=Geoff|date=28 September 2003|publisher=''The Age''|accessdate=20 January 2010}}</ref> New jackets were introduced in 2005<ref name="joffa1" /> and 2010. The last version featured the logo of the [[Epilepsy Foundation of Victoria]] on front and back. In 2010, Corfe said that he would retire the gold jacket "if the Pies win the flag."<ref name="HSAug22">{{cite news|url=http://www.adelaidenow.com.au/sport/afl/secret-life-of-joffa/story-e6frecnu-1225908015295|title= Secret life of Joffa|last=Hadfield|first=Shelley|date=20 August 2010|publisher=''Herald Sun''|accessdate=22 August 2010}}</ref> He had the jacket on by the sixth minute of the final quarter of the [[2010 AFL Grand Final#Grand Final Replay, 2 October 2010|2010 AFL Grand Final replay]],<ref name="HSun31010">{{cite web|url=http://www.adelaidenow.com.au/sport/afl/afl-grand-final-winners-collingwood-looking-forward-to-proud-new-chapter/story-e6freck3-1225933306124|title=AFL Grand Final winners Collingwood looking forward to proud new chapter|last=Rolfe|first=Peter|date=3 October 2010|publisher=''Herald Sun''|accessdate=3 October 2010}}</ref> as Collingwood stormed to an easy win over [[St Kilda Football Club|St Kilda]].
Following a turbulent 10-year history the gold jacket was officially retired<ref>[http://joffasfrontpage.com/first_73_73.html Joffa's Front Page]</ref> after the 2010 premiership win. The jacket was auctioned on [[eBay]] for $3,900, with all proceeds going to the Epilepsy Foundation of Victoria.
In 2011, a new version – known as the "People's Jacket" – was created by the Epilepsy Foundation and is worn by Collingwood supporters, usually children, after a win.
==Early life and family== Corfe, one of four boys and three girls, came from a working-class family in Melbourne.<ref name="HSAug22" /> His mother, June Murphy, suffered from alcoholism and drug addiction.<ref name="AgeSep24">{{cite news|url=http://www.theage.com.au/victoria/joffas-other-side-guardian-angel-to-the-lost-20110923-1kpp2.html |title=Joffa's other side, guardian angel to the lost |last=Johnston |first=Chris |date=24 September 2011 |publisher=''The Age'' |accessdate=13 October 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111026013854/http://www.theage.com.au/victoria/joffas-other-side-guardian-angel-to-the-lost-20110923-1kpp2.html |archivedate=26 October 2011 |df= }}</ref> His father, Robert Corfe, who also suffered from alcoholism and drug addiction, drove a truck, delivered mail and had various other "bum jobs". When he was a young child, Corfe's family moved around various suburbs in Melbourne, escaping debt and financial obligations.<ref name="AgeSep24" /> By the time he was 14, in the mid 1970s, Corfe had left home and was living at the [[Allambie Reception Centre|Allambie Boys Home]] in [[Burwood East, Victoria|East Burwood]], where he stayed for about five years. During this time he recalls a "lovely couple" taking him to [[Victoria Park, Melbourne|Victoria Park]], where he saw his first game of football.<ref name="HSAug22" /><ref name="AgeAug28">{{cite news|url=http://www.theage.com.au/afl/afl-news/kicking-on-after-a-school-of-hard-knocks-20100827-13w0r.html|title= Kicking on after a school of hard knocks|last=Flanagan|first=Martin|date=28 August 2010|publisher=''The Age''|accessdate=28 August 2010}}</ref> His six siblings also lived in and out of public homes and foster care throughout their early years due to their parents' chronic instability and poverty.<ref name="HSAug22" />
In his early adolescence, Corfe drifted between different jobs and different homes; his living situation alternating between public housing, his unstable family and the streets.<ref name="HSAug22" /> He was homeless for four years in his late teenage years, until he got a job at a plastics factory in Hawthorn and was able to escape homelessness.<ref name="AgeSep24" />
Today, he is single, working and a social advocate.<ref name="HSAug22" /> His daughter, Emma, was diagnosed at 13 (2003) with [[epilepsy]] and he has since become a vocal advocate for the Epilepsy Foundation of Victoria.<ref name="HSAug22" /> He likes to read books and spend time with his three grandchildren – Simon, Jeffrey and Destiny-Pearl, who are [[Indigenous Australians|indigenous]].<ref name="HSAug22" /> He has close connections with the indigenous community at Lake Tyers.<ref name="GKFR">{{cite web|title=Joffa the Movie |url=http://filmreviews.net.au/?p=1480 |publisher=Greg King, FilmReviews.net.au, 5 September 2010 |accessdate=10 September 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100908014621/http://filmreviews.net.au/?p=1480 |archivedate= 8 September 2010 |df= }}</ref> He has not had a drink of [[alcohol (drug)|alcohol]] since 2000. "I never had a problem with it, but I have major problems with people who are intoxicated. They just don't make sense."<ref name="HSAug22" />
As well as being a charity fundraiser and a supporter of disadvantaged people, Corfe appears as a guest speaker at sportsmen's nights and social and charity events.
==Employment== Corfe is employed as a welfare worker at the Anchorage Hostel,<ref>http://www.melbourne.homeless.org.au/specialised.html</ref> a [[Salvation Army]] refuge for homeless men.<ref name="AgeSep24" /> He does night shift from 11 pm to 8.30 am.<ref name="AgeSep24" /> The hostel "houses 57 men, with an average age of about 50. Half have mental health issues or brain injuries, their life administered by the state trustee. Many are alcoholics or drug users. Some choose to be outsiders, some have had that forced upon them."<ref name="AgeSep24" />
Eddie McGuire says that he is a big fan of Corfe's. "He's as rough as hessian undies", says McGuire, "but he has a tremendous intellect and an amazing capacity for good."<ref name="AgeSep24" />
Corfe is so well known in Australia that ''[[The Australian]]'' newspaper used his name in an opinion piece on the [[National Broadband Network]] debate.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/opinion/theres-always-the-joffa-option/story-e6frg71x-1225948014222|title=There's always the Joffa option|date=5 November 2010|publisher=''The Australian''|accessdate=9 August 2013}}</ref>
Throughout the [[2012 AFL season]], Corfe, with Ben Bronx, debuted the ''Bronxy & Joffa'' show on [[YouTube]]. On the weekly show they would discuss the biggest talking points of the previous round and preview the coming week of Australian Rules football.
==Charity work== [[File:Joffa and Joffre.jpg|right|thumb|225px|Joffa Corfe and Joffre Pearce about to depart Murray Bridge on the final leg of their fundraising ride from Melbourne to Adelaide.]]
===Ride to Football Park=== From 30 July 2011<ref>{{cite web|title=Joffa cycles to support epilepsy|url=http://www.thecourier.com.au/news/local/news/general/joffa-cycles-to-support-epilepsy/2230314.aspx/|publisher=The Courier, 18 July 2011|accessdate=9 August 2011}}</ref> to 6 August 2011, Joffa Corfe and Joffre Pearce,<ref>{{cite web|title=Joffa cycling through for Epilepsy Foundation |url=http://www.stawelltimes.com.au/news/local/news/general/joffa-cycling-through-for-epilepsy-foundation/2227561.aspx |publisher=The Stawell Times-News, 15 July 2011 |accessdate=4 August 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111007165853/http://www.stawelltimes.com.au/news/local/news/general/joffa-cycling-through-for-epilepsy-foundation/2227561.aspx |archivedate= 7 October 2011 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Joffa Corfe to hit Stawell on Sunday|url=http://www.mailtimes.com.au/news/local/news/general/joffa-corfe-to-hit-stawell-on-sunday/2242155.aspx|publisher=The Wimmera Mail-Times, 29 July 2011|accessdate=4 August 2011}}</ref> father of [[Danyle Pearce]], a player with the [[Fremantle Football Club]] in the [[Australian Football League]], completed a fundraising bicycle ride from [[Rockbank, Victoria|Rockbank]], outside of Melbourne, to [[Football Park]] in [[Adelaide]].<ref>[http://joffasfrontpage.com/ride_to_aami_261.html Ride to AAMI - Joffa's Front Page]</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Joffa rolls through town|url=http://www.dimboolacourier.com.au/news.php?newsid=466|publisher=Dimboola Courier, 2 August 2011|accessdate=5 August 2011}}</ref> Along the way they met up with local football clubs, and gave and received encouragement.<ref>{{cite web|title=A JOFFA YOU CAN’T REFUSE|url=http://www.theweeklyadvertiser.com.au/blog/2011/08/03/a-joffa-you-can%E2%80%99t-refuse/|publisher=The Wimmera Weekly Advertiser, 3 August 2011|accessdate=8 August 2011}}</ref> [[Olympic Games|Olympic]] Gold Medalist [[Brett Aitken]] joined the riders on their final leg.
The ride raised over $1,300<ref>{{cite web|title=The Ride To Football Park For Epilepsy|url=http://www.everydayhero.com.au/jeffrey_corfe/|publisher=Epilepsy Foundation of Victoria, 31 August 2011|accessdate=8 August 2011}}</ref> for the [[Epilepsy Foundation of Victoria]]’s Parent Epilepsy Support Network.
===2011 Flood Relief Charity Match=== During one of the breaks in the [[Australian Football League pre-season competition|NAB Cup]] three-way match at [[Docklands Stadium]] on 12 February 2011, "Joffa" turned out as a player<ref>[http://joffasfrontpage.com/celeb_match_245.html Celeb Match, photos]</ref> for the "Collingwood" team in a charity fund-raiser<ref name="HSFeb17">{{cite news|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/sport/afl/scott-pendlebury-suggests-afl-match-for-raise-money-for-flood-victims/story-e6frf9jf-1225986967744|title=Collingwood's Scott Pendlebury suggests AFL match for raise money for flood victims |last=Schulz|first=Matthew|date=13 January 2011|publisher=''Herald Sun''|accessdate=17 February 2011}}</ref> against a celebrity "Carlton" team. Funds were raised to aid victims of the devastating [[2010–2011 Queensland floods|Queensland floods]].
===RecLink football=== Joffa is an active supporter of RecLink football in general and the ''Collingwood Knights'' team in particular.<ref name="AgeAug28" /> RecLink is a national organisation that provides access to sporting and recreational opportunities as a form of social therapy for people experiencing social and economic disadvantage.<ref>[http://www.goforyourlife.vic.gov.au/hav/articles.nsf/pages/RecLink?open RecLink website]</ref>
===Joffa's Walk for Epilepsy=== He has been an active and successful fundraiser for the [[Epilepsy Foundation of Victoria]] for many years. ''Joffa’s Walk for Epilepsy'' was run in 2006.<ref name="heraldsun10">{{cite news|url=http://www.collingwoodfc.com.au/newsfeatures/news/newsarticle/tabid/5586/newsid/32762/default.aspx |title=Joffa’s Walk for Epilepsy |last=Brown |first=Clinton |date=2 October 2006 |publisher=BigPond |accessdate=17 August 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110724173602/http://www.collingwoodfc.com.au/newsfeatures/news/newsarticle/tabid/5586/newsid/32762/default.aspx |archivedate=24 July 2011 |df= }}</ref>
===Bobblehead doll=== In conjunction with the release of ''[[Joffa: The Movie]]'', Joffa the Movie Action Figure Bobblehead Dolls<ref name="heraldsun11">{{cite news|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/entertainment/movies/joffa-hits-big-time-in-his-first-film/story-e6frf9h6-1225875726006|title=Joffa hits big time in his first film|last=Brown|first=Terry|date=5 June 2010|publisher=''Herald ''Sun|accessdate=17 August 2010}}</ref> are currently being sold by the [[Epilepsy Foundation of Victoria]] to raise funds for epilepsy research.<ref>[http://www.joffasfrontpage.com/first_73_73.html Joffa the Movie Action Figure Bobblehead Doll]</ref>
===Carlton Football Club=== When the [[Carlton Football Club]], long time nemesis of Joffa's beloved [[Collingwood Football Club|Collingwood]], got itself into "dire financial trouble" in 2007,<ref name="heraldsun07">{{cite news|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/victoria/joffa-goes-to-the-dark-side/story-e6frf7kx-1111112918621|title=Joffa goes to the dark side |last=Schulz|first=Matthew|date=31 January 2007|publisher=''Herald Sun''|accessdate=8 September 2010}}</ref> Joffa appeared in Carlton colours outside [[Flinders Street railway station]] "to show he was serious about helping the club".<ref name="heraldsun07" /> He described Carlton as one of the four "powerhouses of the competition"<ref name="heraldsun07" /> and said he would "do anything" to keep them from disappearing in a merger with another club.<ref name="heraldsun07" /> "They're the club I love to hate, so I'd hate to see them go."<ref name="heraldsun07" />
===Bronxy & Joffa join rally to recognise Somaliland=== On 22 February 2012, during a tour of the [[United Kingdom]] with Ben Bronx, Joffa and Bronxy joined a rally to recognise [[Somaliland]] as an independent country, and to seek recognition from the [[Government of the United Kingdom|British government]]. They raised awareness of the cause by rallying through the streets of London and by posting a video online that went viral.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HMKb4EzELd0 Bronxy & Joffa Join Rally In London To Recognise Somaliland (Wednesday 22 February 2012)]</ref>
==Joffa: The Movie== Inspired by the classic Australian movie ''[[The Club (play)|The Club]]'',<ref name="HSJul30">{{cite web|title=A finals cinema fling for crusty Pie Jeff 'Joffa' Corfe|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/joffa-the-collingwood-super-fan-to-star-in-his-very-own-movie/story-e6frf7kx-1225898639990|publisher=Terry Brown, ''Herald Sun'', 30 July 2010|accessdate=18 August 2010}}</ref> producer-director Chris Liontos decided to make his own film about [[Australian rules football|Aussie rules football]] "''through the eyes of the most passionate supporter in the country''."<ref name="HSFeb9">{{cite web|title=Joffa the Collingwood Super Fan to star in his very own movie|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/joffa-the-collingwood-super-fan-to-star-in-his-very-own-movie/story-e6frf7jo-1225828042111|publisher=Terry Brown,'' Herald Sun'', 9 February 2010|accessdate=16 August 2010}}</ref> ''[[Joffa: The Movie]]'' was released nationally on 2 September 2010. For such "''an ultra-low budget movie to get a national cinema release – this has never happened (before)''," Liontos said.<ref name="HSJul30" /> The official website<ref>[http://www.joffathemovie.com/ Official website] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100729015154/http://joffathemovie.com/ |date=29 July 2010 }}</ref> describes Joffa's life outside football as "hilariously funny" and promises "a journey that explores mateship, trust and the human spirit".
'''The DVD''' of the movie<ref>[http://www.jbhifionline.com.au/dvd/dvd-genres/special-interest-documentary/joffa-the-movie/577910 DVD – JB HiFi]</ref> was released in December 2010 by [[Madman Entertainment]]. In reviewing the DVD, [[Filmink]] said: "A ubiquitous, beguiling weirdo, Joffa is warm and funny playing himself..."<ref>[http://www.filmink.com.au/review/joffa-the-movie-dvd/ Filmink – Joffa: The Movie]</ref> The DVD includes a full set of commentaries, bloopers and footage of Collingwood's 2010 Grand Final win celebrations.<ref>[http://www.madman.com.au/catalogue/view/14331/joffa-the-movie Madman DVD details], 1 December 2010</ref>
==Biography== [[File:Cover of book by Joffa Corfe - "Joffa - Isn’t That Life?".jpg|right|thumb|225px]] Joffa's book was launched by Father [[Bob Maguire]] on Thursday, 11 June.<ref>[http://www.busybird.com.au/?page_id=4798 Busybird Publishing] ''Joffa: Isn’t That Life?''. Retrieved 12 May 2015.</ref><ref>[http://catalogue.nla.gov.au/Record/6818047 National Library of Australia] ''Joffa : isn't that life? / Jeff 'Joffa' Corfe''. Retrieved 12 May 2015.</ref>
#{{cite book | last = Corfe | first = Jeff "Joffa" | authorlink =Joffa Corfe | title = Joffa: Isn’t That Life? | publisher = Busybird Publishing | year = 2015 | location = Montmorency, Vic. | pages = | url = http://www.busybird.com.au/?page_id=4798 | doi = | id = | isbn = 978 1 925260 29 8}}
The book was reviewed by [[Rohan Connolly]] in ''[[The Age]]'' <ref>{{cite news | last = Connolly | first = Rohan | date = 11 June 2015 | title = How does footy mend its broken heart? | work = The Age | url = http://www.theage.com.au/afl/afl-news/how-does-footy-mend-its-broken-heart-20150611-ghl0j8 | accessdate = 15 June 2015 }}</ref> and Peter Rolfe in the Sunday ''[[Herald Sun]]''.<ref>{{cite news | last = Rolfe | first = Peter | date = 7 June 2015 | title = Collingwood super fan Jeff ‘Joffa’ Corfe fears corporate ‘suits’ are ruining AFL | work = Sunday Herald Sun | url = http://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/victoria/collingwood-super-fan-jeff-joffa-corfe-fears-corporate-suits-are-ruining-afl/story-fnpp4dl6-1227386586332 | accessdate = 15 June 2015 }}</ref>
==Controversy== When [[Prime Minister of Australia|Prime Minister]], [[Julia Gillard]], tried to rally voters during the [[Australian federal election, 2010|2010 Federal election]] by calling for a "unity ticket" of people who hated the [[Collingwood Football Club]], Corfe reacted by saying that she had "lost his vote".<ref name="HSAug19">{{cite news|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/special-reports/collingwood-say-julia-gillard-has-lost-votes-after-saying-she-hates-pies/story-fn5ko0pw-1225907286357|title=Collingwood fans say Julia Gillard has lost votes after saying she hates Pies|last=Schulz|first=Matthew|date=19 August 2010|publisher=''Herald Sun''|accessdate=19 August 2010}}</ref> When she was asked to explain her comments, Gillard said that she had no choice but to "stick with her footy principles".<ref name="HSAug19" /> Joffa said, "For a Prime Minister to jump on the anti-Collingwood bandwagon, I reckon it’s a bit poor... We don’t need that stuff on the national political stage."<ref name="HSAug19" /> He added: "I have gone to the Greens, she’s finished."<ref name="HSAug19" />
In 2008 Corfe created controversy when photographs of him posing with two rifles in the manner of Melbourne criminal [[Chopper Read]] were posted on a Collingwood supporters' internet forum. His actions were criticised by gun control activists but Collingwood's president, Eddie McGuire, defended Corfe's character.<ref name="heraldsun1"/><ref name="australian1">{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/footy-fanatic-shot-down-for-gun-fun/story-0-1111118208916|title=Collingwood AFL fan Jeff 'Joffa' Corfe slammed for website photo with guns |last=Trickey|first=Gareth|date=3 December 2008|publisher=''The Australian''|accessdate=20 January 2010}}</ref>
After a ban on the use of the term "white maggot" in reference to umpires was introduced at [[the Gabba]] in 2007, Corfe defended the right of supporters to use the term. He compared security at the ground to [[Gestapo]].<ref name="maggot">{{cite news|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/victoria/wrangle-over-white-maggot/story-e6frf7l6-1111113430471|title=Wrangle over 'white maggot'|last=Tame|first=Adrian |author2=Black, Anthony |date=29 April 2007|publisher=[[Herald Sun]]|accessdate=2 July 2012}}</ref>
Although Corfe has been the highest profile member of the Collingwood cheer squad, he has not always had a comfortable relationship with other fans and club staff.<ref name="perthnow1">{{cite news|url=http://www.perthnow.com.au/sport/afl/cheer-squads-put-on-notice/story-e6frg1xu-1111119105416|title=AFL fans warned to behave... or else |last=Critchley|first=Cheryl|date=11 March 2009|publisher=PerthNow|accessdate=20 January 2010}}</ref> In 2003 leaflets criticising his behaviour and including his home address were distributed at a Collingwood match.<ref name="age2"/>
In round 18 of the [[2002 AFL season]], in a match between Collingwood and their archrival [[Carlton Football Club|Carlton]], Corfe drew attention to the fact that Carlton were going to finish last that year by waving an oversized [[Wooden spoon (award)|wooden spoon]]. The spoon was initially confiscated, though it was later put on display at the Collingwood club rooms. Collingwood won that game by 108 points.<ref name="joffa1" /><ref name="age3" /><ref name="age5">{{cite news|url=http://www.theage.com.au/news/geoff-mcclure/pies-ready-to-dish-up-blues-spoon/2005/08/09/1123353319802.html|title=Pies ready to dish up Blues' spoon|last=McClure|first=Geoff|date=10 August 2005|publisher=''The Age''|accessdate=20 January 2010}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|3}}
==External links== * [https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1815771/ Joffa: The Movie] at IMDb * [http://player.video.news.com.au/heraldsun/#1570423464 Jeff Corfe reveals the family man behind the gold jacket] Herald Sun video interview, 20 August 2010 * [http://www.epinet.org.au/articles/client_stories_-_people_living_with_epilepsy/emma_corfe_-_a_passion_for_more_than_just_football/ Emma Corfe: People living with epilepsy] Epilepsy Foundation of Victoria
{{Collingwood Football Club}}

{{Infobox Stadium | stadium_name=John M. Belk Arena | nickname=McKillop Court | image=[[Image:BelkArenaDavidson.JPG|250px]] | location=200 Baker Drive
[[Davidson, North Carolina]], [[United States|USA]] | coordinates={{Coord|35.499278|-80.840521|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground=September 1988 | built= | opened=November 12, 1989 | closed= | demolished= | owner=Davidson College | operator=Davidson College | surface=Hardwood | construction_cost=$12.3 million
(${{formatprice|{{Inflation|US|12300000|1989}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars{{inflation-fn|US}}) | architect=O'Dell & Associates, Inc. | general_contractor=Rodgers Builders, Inc. | tenants=Davidson College men's and women's basketball
Davidson College women's volleyball | seating_capacity=5,700 }} '''John M. Belk Arena''' is a 5,295-seat multi-purpose [[arena]], located on the campus of [[Davidson College]], in [[Davidson, North Carolina]], [[United States]]. It is named for Davidson alumnus and benefactor [[John M. Belk]] (1920–2007), class of 1943. As the centerpiece of the Baker Sports Complex, it is home to the [[Davidson Wildcats]] men's and women's [[basketball]] teams, the [[Davidson Wildcats wrestling]] team, and the women's [[volleyball]] team. The playing surface is named McKillop Court in honor of current men's basketball coach [[Bob McKillop]], who has coached the most victories in the school's history.{{cite web |title=Davidson Surprises Bob McKillop by Naming Program's Court After Him|first=Mike|last=DeCourcy|url=http://www.sportingnews.com/ncaa-basketball/story/2014-02-01/davidson-names-court-after-bob-mckillop-wildcats-stephen-curry-belk-arena|work=[[Sporting News]]|date=February 1, 2014|accessdate=February 1, 2014}} [[Bob Dylan]] performed at the arena during his [[Never Ending Tour|2006 North American Tour]] on May 2, 2006. ==See also== * [[List of NCAA Division I basketball arenas]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== * [http://davidsonwildcats.com/sports/2008/6/11/sidebar_368.aspx?path=mbball Davidson College Athletics - Belk Arena] * [http://www3.davidson.edu/cms/x15092.xml Davidson College - John M. Belk Arena] {{Davidson Wildcats men's basketball navbox}} {{Atlantic 10 Conference basketball venue navbox}} {{Charlotte sports venues}} {{North Carolina NCAA Division I women's college volleyball venues navbox}} [[Category:Sports venues in Mecklenburg County, North Carolina]] [[Category:Basketball venues in North Carolina]] [[Category:College basketball venues in the United States]] [[Category:College volleyball venues in the United States]] [[Category:Davidson Wildcats basketball]] [[Category:Indoor arenas in North Carolina]] [[Category:1989 establishments in North Carolina]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1989]] {{NorthCarolina-stadium-stub}}

revision.text:
[[File:Lead Apron worn by Dr Danny Sands.jpg|thumb|A rubber coated lead apron protects organs from exposure to x-rays.]] A '''lead apron''' or '''leaded apron''' is a type of [[personal protective equipment|protective clothing]] that acts as a radiation shield. It is constructed of a thin rubber exterior and an interior of [[lead]] in the shape of a hospital apron. The purpose of the lead apron is to reduce exposure of a hospital patient to [[x-ray]]s to vital organs that are potentially exposed to [[ionizing radiation]] during [[medical imaging]] that uses x-rays ([[radiography]], [[fluoroscopy]], [[computed tomography]]).
==Specific anatomic regions== Protection of the [[reproductive organs]] with a lead apron is considered important because [[DNA]] changes to [[sperm]] or [[egg]] cells of the patient may pass on genetic defects to the offspring of the patient, causing serious and unnecessary hardship for child and parents.
The [[thyroid]] gland is especially vulnerable to x-ray exposure. Care should be taken to place a lead apron over the thyroid gland before taking [[Dentistry|dental]] radiographs.<ref>A Patient's Guide to Medical Imaging By Ronald Eisenberg, JD, MD, FACR, Alexander Margulis, MD</ref><ref>Current oral and maxillofacial imaging,Thomas F. Razmus, Gail F. Williamson, Page 107</ref> Aprons used for dental imaging should include thyroid collars.
==See also== *[[Radiation shielding]] *[[Instruments used in radiology]] *[[Lead shielding]] *[[Birth defects]]
==References== {{Reflist}} {{Radiation protection|state=uncollapsed}} [[Category:Protective gear]] [[Category:Radiation protection]]

revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=April 2016}}
'''Martin Rowley''' has been a professional golf [[caddie]] since the late 1980s and has been both secretary and chairman of the European Tour Caddies Association.
A former Scholar of the world famous Repton school, he has a passion for all sports and the values they bring to the people participating and the communities they live in.
Rowley is a regular feature on the [[PGA European Tour]] and was at [[Ian Woosnam]]'s side during his successful captaincy at the [[2006 Ryder Cup]].
He has also worked with the following Ryder Cup players: [[Eamonn Darcy]], [[Ken Brown (golfer)|Ken Brown]], [[Darren Clarke]] and [[Miguel Ángel Jiménez]]. He currently caddies for [[Ian Garbutt]] and is behind golfnavigation.co.uk.
He is now more well known for assisting young aspiring golfers and is a regular fixture in The Coach and Horses public house, Worcester, where he will happily regail golfing tales over a fine pint with allcomers.
== Sources == * [http://www.golfnavigation.co.uk/ Golf Navigation] * [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sportacademy/hi/sa/golf/features/newsid_2078000/2078952.stm BBC Sports Academy Profile] * [http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/article1135800.ece Caddie is ready to pack his bags] * [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/golf/3004157/Caddies-go-up-in-the-world.html Caddies go up in the world]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Rowley, Martin}} [[Category:Caddies]] [[Category:Living people]]

revision.text:
{{Unreferenced|date=August 2016}} {{Infobox Basketball club | color1 = white | color2 = #EF7F1B | name = Melikşah Üniversitesi | nickname = | logo = Melikşah Üniversitesi SK logo.png | imagesize = 180px | leagues = [[Turkish Basketball League (TBL)|TBL]] | founded = 2013 | dissolved = 2016 | history = '''Melikşah Üniversitesi'''
2013–2014
'''Mondi Melikşah Üniversitesi'''
2014–2016 | arena = Recep Mamur Sports Hall | capacity = 500 | location = [[Kayseri]], [[Turkey]] | president = Veli Demirci | coach = Murat Aşkın | championships = | website = | h_body = EF7F1B | h_pattern_b = _sides_on_white | h_shorts = EF7F1B | h_pattern_s = _sides_on_white | a_body = EF7F1B | a_pattern_b =_whitesides | a_shorts = EF7F1B | a_pattern_s =_whitesides }} '''Melikşah Üniversitesi Gençlik ve Spor Kulübü''', commonly known as '''Melikşah Üniversitesi''', was a Turkish professional [[basketball]] club based in [[Kayseri]]. During its three-year existence, the club played in the [[Turkish Basketball League (TBL)|TBL]], the second tier of Turkish basketball. The team was founded by Kayseri Melikşah Üniversitesi in 2013. Their home arena was Recep Mamur Sports Hall, which has a capacity of 500 seats. The team was sponsored by Mondi, which is a furniture company, and therefore was named '''Mondi Melikşah Üniversitesi''' during its last two seasons. ==Season by season== {| class="wikitable" style="font-size:85%" !Season !Tier !League !{{Tooltip|Pos.|Position after Playoffs}} !{{Tooltip|W–L|Wins-Losses}} |- |style="background:#efefef;"|2013–14 | align="center"|3 | [[Turkish Basketball Second League|TB3L]] | style="background:#BBF3BB;" align="center"| 1st | |- |style="background:#efefef;"|2014–15 | align="center"|2 | [[Turkish Basketball First League|TB2L]] | align="center"| 7th |
21–16 |- |style="background:#efefef;"|2015–16 | align="center"|2 | [[Turkish Basketball First League|TBL]] | align="center"| 11th |
14–20 |- |} == External links == * [http://basketball.eurobasket.com/team/Turkey/Meliksah_Universitesi_Kayseri/19379 Eurobasket.com page] {{DEFAULTSORT:Meliksah Universitesi S.K.}} [[Category:Basketball teams in Turkey]] [[Category:Basketball teams established in 2013]] [[Category:Sport in Kayseri]] {{Turkey-basketball-team-stub}}

{{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}} {{infobox country at games | NOC = MEX | NOCname = [[Mexican Olympic Committee]] | games = Summer Olympics | year = 1900 | flagcaption = | oldcode = | website = {{url|www.com.org.mx }} {{es icon}} | location = [[Paris]] | competitors = 4 | sports = 1 | flagbearer = | rank = 20 | gold = 0 | silver = 0 | bronze = 1 | officials = | appearances = auto | app_begin_year = 1900 | app_end_year = | summerappearances = | winterappearances = | seealso = }} '''[[Mexico]]''' competed at the modern Olympic Games for the first time at the '''[[1900 Summer Olympics]]''' in [[Paris]], [[France]]. ==Medalists== [[Gold medal]]s were not given at the 1900 Games. A [[silver medal]] was given for a first place, and a [[bronze medal]] was given for second. The [[International Olympic Committee]] has retroactively assigned gold, silver, and bronze medals to competitors who earned 1st, 2nd, and 3rd place finishes, respectively, in order to bring early Olympics in line with current awards. ===Bronze=== * Mexico — polo, men's competition ==Results by event== ===Polo=== {{Main article|Polo at the 1900 Summer Olympics}} Mexico was one of four nations to compete in the first Olympic polo event. The Mexican foursome tied for third place despite losing their only match. {| class=wikitable !
