revision.text:
The definition of '''ultra-distance cycling''' is far more vague than in [[Ultramarathon|ultra running]] (any race longer than a [[marathon]]) or in [[ultra-triathlon]] (any race longer than an [[Ironman Triathlon]]). Any [[Cycle sport|bike race]] longer than a [[century ride]], which is {{convert|100|mi|km}}, is sometimes considered to be ultra-distance cycling. However, such events are relatively common, so using a longer distance to define the category is more useful, such as any race that is longer than {{convert|200|km|mi}}, {{convert|300|km|mi}} or even a double century, {{convert|200|mi|km}}.
Bike races that cover these distances but which are split into [[Race stage|stages]] do not fit most definitions of ultra-distance races - the clock needs to run continuously from start to finish. Even so, extra-long stages within a longer race may be long enough to be an ultra-distance race by themselves. In addition, any team events in which individual cyclists do not complete the full distance are not considered to be ultra-distance.
Bike races that can be described as ultra-distance are organized below according to the type or format of the race. This is not an exhaustive list of such races, but the longest, most important (as measured by the level of media interest), or most popular (as measured by the number of participants) races within each category are mentioned.
==Track cycling== In the early days of bicycle racing in the late 1800s, [[six-day racing]] on [[velodrome]]s was popular. Only the original race format is a true ultra-distance cycling race as defined here because it was a simple test of how far an individual cyclist could ride during the six day-long event. The format evolved away from this to involve teams of two riding in a relay format. Later, the non-stop nature of the race was changed to only race during part of each day.
==Road racing==
=== Professional === In the early days of professional [[road bicycle racing]] there were many one-day road races and stages in [[Grand Tour (cycling)|grand tours]] that were much longer than those of today. [[Bordeaux-Paris]] in France was the longest one-day, annual professional bike race; it had a route of about {{convert|560|km|mi}} and was run almost every year between 1891 and 1988. After 1988, the longest one-day professional bike race became [[Porto–Lisboa]] in Portugal, which was about {{convert|330|km|mi}} long. Porto-Lisboa was last held in 2004, and [[Milan-San Remo]] in Italy has since then been the longest race at {{convert|298|km|mi}}.
[[Paris–Brest–Paris]] was a professional bike race that covered a massive {{convert|1200|km|mi}} in France, and was only held every 10 years from 1891 until 1951, but has since continued as a [[randonneuring]] event (see below).
Cycling's grand tours used to include far longer stages than they do today. The longest ever [[Tour de France]] stage was {{convert|482|km|mi}} in the [[1919 Tour de France|1919 Tour]] and that year every one of the 15 stages was more than {{convert|300|km|mi}} long. The longest ever stage in the [[Giro d’Italia]] was {{convert|430|km|mi}} in the [[1914 Giro d'Italia|1914 Giro]] and that year 5 of the 8 stages were longer than {{convert|400|km|mi}}. The [[Vuelta a España]] did not begin until 1935 and the [[1935 Vuelta a España|first edition]] was when its longest-ever stage was held, which was {{convert|310|km|mi}}. In modern grand tours, stages longer than {{convert|200|km|mi}} are increasingly rare and the limit set by the [[Union Cycliste Internationale]] (UCI) for any individual stage during a stage race is 240 km.<ref>{{cite web|first=Andrew|last=Hood|title=The mapmakers: Creating the Tour de France route|url=http://velonews.competitor.com/2016/02/news/road/the-mapmakers-creating-the-tour-de-france-route_393564|website=Velonews|publisher=Competitor Group, Inc.|accessdate=5 February 2016}}</ref>
===Supported ultracycling races=== There are no longer any true ultra-distance bike races (i.e., that are longer than {{convert|300|km|mi}}) that are affiliated with cycling's main governing body, the UCI; most modern ultra-distance races are instead affiliated with the [https://www.ultracycling.com/ UltraMarathon Cycling Association] (UMCA). By far the best-known of these races is the [[Race Across America]] (RAAM), a non-stop race across the United States that covers {{convert|4860|km|mi}}.
In this format of racing, the cyclists race individually ([[Drafting (aerodynamics)|drafting]] and group riding are not allowed) but each cyclist has at least one support vehicle and a team of support staff. This specific format of racing is often referred to as "ultracycling", which is why it would be incorrect to refer to all ultra-distance cyling as ultracycling. Many ultracycling races include a team category that operates in a relay format and so doesn’t meet the criteria for an ultra-distance cycling race used here (in which individuals must ride the complete distance).
Other ultracycling races include the [http://www.theraceacrosseurope.com Race ACross Europe] (RACE), which is {{convert|4722|km|mi}} long. The oldest ultracycling race in Europe{{Citation needed|date=December 2016}} is the [http://www.glocknerman.com?lang=en Glocknerman], an Austrian cycling event with a distance of {{convert|1000|km|mi}} that was first held in 1997. The [http://www.raceacrossthealps.com/ Race Across The Alps] is only {{convert|540|km|mi}} long but contains over {{convert|13000|m|ft}} of climbing and so the organizers claim it to be the hardest one-day race in the world.<ref>{{cite web|title=15. Race across the Alps, 26. Juni 2015|url=http://www.raceacrossthealps.com/|website=Race Across The Alps|accessdate=16 January 2016}}</ref>
The first Race Across Russia was held in 2013 as a non-stop team relay event with a total distance of about {{convert|9200|km|mi}} between Moscow and Vladivostok. In 2015 it became the [http://www.redbull.com/en/bike/events/1331759980752/red-bull-trans-siberian-extreme-2016 Red Bull Trans-Siberian Extreme] with a solo category and the route was split into 15 separate stages, each between {{convert|300|km|mi}} and {{convert|1400|km|mi}} long.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Wynn|first1=Nigel|title=The world's toughest bike race: 9200km across Siberia|url=http://www.cyclingweekly.co.uk/news/latest-news/the-worlds-toughest-bike-race-9200km-across-siberia-173656|website=Cycling Weekly|publisher=Time Inc. (UK) Ltd.|accessdate=16 January 2016}}</ref>
===Road time trials=== 12-hour and 24-hour road cycling [[Individual time trial|time trials]] have been around for a long time and are still common. In these events, cyclists attempt to ride the maximum distance possible within the time limit. The current [[Cycling records#24 Hours record|24 hour record]] is over {{convert|800|km|mi}} on a traditional bicycle and over {{convert|1200|km|mi}} in a [[velomobile]]. In 2014, the UMCA revived interest in the [[Cycling records#World Endurance record for distance in a calendar year|highest annual mileage record]], which was last set in 1939 by [[Tommy Godwin (cyclist born 1912)|Tommy Godwin]] at {{convert|120805|km|mi}}. This involves riding the maximum distance possible within a 12-month period. In early 2016, Kurt Searvogel broke the record, achieving a distance of {{convert|122433|km|mi}} in one year or {{convert|335|km|mi}} per day.<ref>{{cite web|last1=MacMichael|first1=Simon|title=Kurt Searvogel awarded Guinness World Record for distance cycled in a year|url=http://road.cc/content/news/176223-kurt-searvogel-awarded-guinness-world-record-distance-cycled-year|website=road.cc|publisher=Farrelly Atkinson Ltd.|accessdate=23 January 2016}}</ref>
===Unsupported ultracycling & bikepacking road races=== Some races have recently become popular that recall the early era of professional bike racing in which riders were unsupported and raced day and night. The most popular of these is the [[Transcontinental Race]], which covers approximately {{convert|4000|km|mi}} across [[Europe]] and was inspired by the off-road US event called the [[Tour Divide]]. As in ultra-cycling events, there is a mass start, but in bikepacking races, drafting is not allowed and all support is forbidden, so there are no support vehicles and riders must find all of their supplies, accommodation, etc. from commercial sources along the route or bring it with them. Another popular example in this category include the [[Trans Am Bike Race]], which is more than 50% longer than the Transcontinental Race at {{convert|6800|km|mi}}, and so it is currently the longest non-stop bike race in the world. The [[IncaDivide Race|IncaDivide]], is a shorter distance event (1,800km / 1,120mi) which brings the high altitude cycling experience. It is the highest self-supported race that takes riders above 4,920 meters (16,140 feet) in the [[Andes|Andes mountains]] of [[Peru]].
Unsupported rides are sometimes done as completely solo attempts outside of organized rides, but are still well-publicized. These often involve riding point to point (including city to city), for example [http://vegasin24.com/ Vegas In 24].
===Randonneuring=== [[Randonneuring]] events (also called brevets or audaxes) are generally non-competitive rides where racing is not the focus; they are ridden more as personal challenges. They also differ from most ultracycling and bikepacking races in that group riding and drafting is allowed. Supplies and accommodation are often provided by the organizers at intermediate checkpoints, but the use of support vehicles is not allowed outside of the checkpoints.
The most famous of this type of event is [[Paris-Brest-Paris]] in France, in which over 5,000 people attempt to complete the {{convert|1200|km|mi}} long route in under 90 hours. The randonnee version evolved from the professional bike race (see above) and is held every four years. There are many similar events of between {{convert|1000|km|mi}} and {{convert|1600|km|mi}} around the world, including [[London-Edinburgh-London]] in the UK and the [http://seattlerando.org/C1200/ Cascade 1200 ] in the USA. For a more complete list, see the page on [[randonneuring]]. There are also many more shorter-distance randonneuring rides, which are typically {{convert|200|km|mi}}, {{convert|300|km|mi}}, or {{convert|600|km|mi}} long.
===Cyclosportives / Gran fondos=== [[Cyclosportive]]s (also known as gran fondos) are mass-participation cycling events. They are far less serious than pure bike races, but times are recorded and prizes are often awarded to the fastest people. The organizers normally provide full support in terms of marking the route and providing feed stations.
The event that proclaims itself to be the "longest Granfondo in the world" follows almost the same route as the professional [[Milan-San Remo]] bike race and is {{convert|296|km|mi}} long.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Granfondo Milan-San Remo cicloturistica: put yourself to the test in the Great Classic of amateur cycling!|url=http://milano-sanremo.org/en/|website=Granfondo Milano-Sanremo cicloturistica|publisher=Nyala Wonder Travel|accessdate=16 January 2016}}</ref> However, there are several similar events that are longer. [[Bordeaux-Paris]] was a professional race until 1988 and returned in 2014 as a cyclosportive with a route of about {{convert|610|km|mi}}. [http://styrkeproven.no/en/races/trondheim Styrkeproven Trondheim-Oslo] is a {{convert|543|km|mi}} long race and cyclosportive in Norway. The [http://sportcommunication.info/TMB/index.php?lang=EN Tour du Mont Blanc] is a {{convert|330|km|mi}} long cyclosportive over mountainous terrain through France, Switzerland, and Italy. Slightly longer still is the [http://www.wysam333.ch/ Wysam 333] in Switzerland at {{convert|333|km|mi}}. There is also the [http://www.mallorca312.com Mallorca 312], which is a {{convert|312|km|mi}} long ride around the island of Mallorca, the Dragon Devil version of the [[Dragon Ride Wales]] cyclosportive in the UK is {{convert|305|km|mi}} long, and the [[Vätternrundan]] cyclosportive that does a tour of the Swedish lake is {{convert|300|km|mi}} long.
In New Zealand, there is the [[Lake Taupo Cycle Challenge]]. The standard cyclosportive option involves a single lap of the lake, which is {{convert|160|km|mi}} long, but there are also options to do two laps in one day for {{convert|320|km|mi}}, with no support on the first lap, or start one day earlier and do four laps, {{convert|640|km|mi}}, which is more of a randonneuring-format event. Every second year there is also an 8 lap option, {{convert|1280|km|mi}} long, but a following support vehicle is required for that version making it more of an ultracycling-format event.
===Century rides=== In the USA, organized [[century ride]]s of {{convert|100|mi|km}} are common, with the format falling between a cyclosportive and a randonnee. There are also many organized double centuries of {{convert|200|mi|km}}, one of the more popular ones being the [[Seattle to Portland Bicycle Classic]], and at least one event even offers {{convert|300|mi|km}} and {{convert|400|mi|km}} options, the [http://www.lawheelmen.org/the-grand-tour-2/ Los Angeles Wheelmen Grand Tour].
===Other road cycling records=== There are a few classic long-distance cycling routes for which time records are kept even though riders normally do not race simultaneously. These include [[Land's End to John o' Groats]] in the United Kingdom, which is about {{convert|1400|km|mi}}. On the longer end of the spectrum, there is [http://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/world-records/fastest-bicycle-journey-cairo-to-cape Cairo to Cape Town] in [[Africa]], which is about {{convert|11000|km|mi}}. This record is currently held by Scottish endurance cyclist [[Mark Beaumont]]<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/world-records/fastest-bicycle-journey-cairo-to-cape|title=Fastest bicycle journey from Cairo to Cape Town (male)|work=Guinness World Records|access-date=2018-09-12|language=en-GB}}</ref>. The longest record of this format is the [[around the world cycling record]], which requires the cyclist to cover {{convert|29000|km|mi}} by bike plus other requirements. A new women's around the world cycling record is currently being attempted by Scottish endurance cyclist [[Jenny Graham]]. In 2012 and 2014, a mass-start event called the [http://www.theadventurists.com/world-cycle-race/ World Cycle Race] was organized based on these rules.
==Gravel biking== In the early days of road bike racing, most roads were not paved, so most races were held primarily on unpaved/dirt/gravel roads. Due to road infrastructure improving with time, road bike racing is now done almost entirely on paved roads. However, in the 21st century, riding and racing road bikes on [[gravel road]]s has gained popularity. One of the longest and most famous of the modern gravel bike races is the [[Dirty Kanza]] in [[Kansas]], USA, which is {{convert|200|mi|km}} long with a 350-miler announced for 2019 and options of 25, 50 and 100 mile courses as well<ref>{{cite web|url=https://dirtykanza.com/distances/dk-xl/|website = Dirty Kanza|title=Dirty Kanza website}}</ref>.
In the UK, the [https://www.dirtyreiver.co.uk/ Dirty Reiver] is a 200 km off road cycling challenge that takes place in [[Hexham]], Northumberland.
==Mountain biking== As on the road, some of the most popular ultra-distance [[mountain bike]] events are 12 and 24 hour time trials, of which there are many all over the world. In addition, there are many mountain bike races of at least {{convert|100|mi|km}}, including the [[Leadville Trail 100 MTB]] (see also the list of [[marathon mountain bike races]]). Very few mountain bike races are longer than {{convert|100|mi|km}} because the average speed on typical mountain biking terrain is much slower than that on the road.
Mountain bike races that take more than 24 hours to compete and in which the clock never stops running are where the bikepacking genre began, in which riders are entirely self-supported (see above for road-based bikepacking events). One of the most famous and popular off-road bikepacking events is the [[Tour Divide]], which covers {{convert|4418|km|mi}} across the Rocky Mountains from Canada, through the USA, and finishes at the Mexican border. The Iditarod Trail Invitational in Alaska is run on [[Fatbike|snow bikes]] in winter and is {{convert|1000|mi|km}} long.<ref>[http://iditarodtrailinvitational.com/]</ref> The most popular off-road bikepacking race in Europe is the Tuscany Trail, which covers {{convert|530|km|mi}} in central Italy.<ref>[http://www.tuscanytrail.it/en]</ref> Also in Italy, the Italy Divide starts at the Roman [[Colosseum|Coliseum]] and finishes at [[Lake Garda]], passing through Siena, Florence and Bologna en route. It mixes technical mountain bike sections with gravel trails.<ref>[http://www.italydivide.it]</ref>
In [[Central Asia]], the Silk Road Mountain Race takes place in Kyrgyzstan, and covers 1,700 km (1,056 mi) in the [[Tian Shan|Tien Shan]] mountain range.<ref>[https://www.silkroadmountainrace.cc/]</ref>
The [[Titan Desert]] is a six-day stage race held in [[Morocco]] with a total distance of over {{convert|600|km|mi}}.
In Australia, the [[Race to the Rock]] is an unsupported race through the [[Outback]] founded by Jesse Carlsson. The course and length differs each year, but generally finishes at [[Uluru]]; the 2018 edition was 3,500 km (2,175 mi) in total, and covered sections of Southern Australia as well as [[Tasmania]].<ref>[https://en-gb.facebook.com/RaceToTheRock/]</ref>
==Climbing-focused== Instead of trying to maximize the distance ridden in one ride, some people try to maximize the height gained in one ride. [[Everesting]] is a challenge that involves repeatedly cycling up and down the same hill multiple times until the total height gain matches the height of [[Mount Everest]], {{convert|8848|meters|feet}}. There are also records for the most height gain achieved within a certain time period, for instance 24 hours.
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://ultracycling.com/ UltraMarathon Cycling Association]

Şti. www.eybinsaat.com | capacity = 7,500 + 360 moving grandstand + 600 press | suites = 7 | record_attendance = | dimensions = {{convert|120|x|110|m|ft|abbr=on}} | acreage = {{convert|8500|m2|sqft|abbr=on}} | volume = | tenants = {{ubl|Judo Grand Prix 2013 Samsun |[[2013 FIBA Europe Under-20 Championship for Women]] |WTF World Taekwondo Grand Prix 2015 |WTF World Para-Taekwondo Championships 2015 |[[2016 Judo Grand Prix Samsun]] |[[2017 Summer Deaflympics]] }} | embedded = | website = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} --> }}
'''Yaşar Doğu Sport Hall''' ({{lang-tr|Yaşar Doğu Spor Salonu}}) is a multi-purpose [[indoor arena]] located in the [[Tekkeköy]] district of [[Samsun]], [[Turkey]]. Named in honor of renowned Turkish sport wrestler [[Yaşar Doğu]] (1913–1961), the sports hall was opened end March 2013.
==History== The sport hall is situated at Sanayi Mah. in Tekkeköy. The construction began in July 2011 and cost {{Turkish lira}}35 million (approx. US$19.5 million), of which 80% was financed by Youth and Sports General Directoriate in [[Ankara]] and the remaining 20% by Samsun Metropolitan Municipality. The building covers an area of {{convert|8500|m2|sqft|abbr=on}} within a ground of {{convert|50000|m2|sqft|abbr=on}}. It has a total seating capacity consisting of 7,500 for spectators, 500 at moving grandstand and 300 for press. The complex houses also four big training halls, two [[squash (sport)|squash]] halls, six big locker rooms, administrative, medical and social facilities.<ref name="h3"/>
The arena's first event hosted was an international Judo tournament organized by the [[International Judo Federation]] (IJF).<ref name="sv"/> In April and May 2013, music concerts for young people and a music festival will take place at the venue. An international amateur boxing tournament was scheduled to be realized in June 2013. It will host on July 4-14 [[2013 FIBA Europe Under-20 Championship for Women]] Division A events.<ref name="h3"/><ref name="fiba"/>
[[Ministry of Youth and Sports (Turkey)|Minister of Youth and Sports]] [[Suat Kılıç]] stated that the 1966-built sports hall with the same name in downtown Samsun having 1,700 seating capacity will be abandoned soon.<ref name="sgsb"/><ref name="sk"/>
==International events hosted== ; 2013 * Judo Grand Prix 2013 Samsun, March 30-31,<ref name="h1"/> * FIBA Europe Under-20 Championship for Women 2013 Samsun, July 4-14,<ref name="tbf"/>
; 2015 * WTF World Taekwondo Grand Prix 2015 Samsun, September 18-20,<ref name="wtf1"/> * WTF World Para-Taekwondo Championships 2015 Samsun, September 15-17,<ref name="wtf2"/>
; 2016 * [[2016 Judo Grand Prix Samsun]], April 01-04
; 2017 * The venue hosted [[Basketball at the 2017 Summer Deaflympics|basketball events]] of the [[2017 Summer Deaflympics]] along with [[Bahattin Ekinci Sports Hall]] located in the same city.<ref name="d"/>

Hazır |date=2013-03-29 |language=Turkish |accessdate=2013-03-30 }}</ref> <ref name="sv">{{cite web |url=http://www.samsun.gov.tr/haber-detay.asp?NewsId=5266 |publisher=Samsun Valiliği |title=Yaşar
